title: Friday, 22nd September, 2017
bodyHTML:
11:01 am
PM11:01am

Hiya

PM11:01am

Obvious pic to use today (and no, not the dotard stuff)

PM11:02am

11:02 am
PM11:02am

Liliane Bettencourt

PM11:02am

As the FMCG team at Morgan Stanley say this morning...

PM11:02am

A Sad Day

11:02 am
PM11:02am

A sad day?

PM11:02am

I mean

PM11:03am

Yes, sad when people die

11:02 am
PM11:03am

But she was 95

PM11:03am

I'll be happy and somewhat shocked (and gaga) if I last till I'm 95

BE11:04am

Are you saying it's less sad when old people die?

11:04 am
PM11:04am

Er, yeah I kinda think it is

BE11:04am

........... interesting. It's a new layer on AV's longstanding "kill the old" thesis.

PM11:05am

You celebrate the life of an old person dying; a youngster dying is typically tragic

11:05 am
PM11:05am

Anyway MOST continue in sombre tone

PM11:05am

In a short statement, L’Oréal’s Chairman and CEO Jean-Paul Agon confirmed “the passing of Mrs Liliane Bettencourt daughter of Eugène Schueller, founder of the L'Oréal Group.” Liliane’s only child, Françoise Bettencourt Meyers added in a separate emailed statement. “In this painful moment for us, I would like to reiterate, on behalf of our family, our entire commitment and loyalty to L’Oréal and to renew my confidence in its President Jean-Paul Agon and his teams worldwide.” Nestle currently owns 23.1% of L'Oreal and the Bettencourt Meyers family owns 33.05% (both stakes were previously held in the holding company Gesparal 1974-2004).

PM11:05am

We expect status quo near term. However, we acknowledge that all options (including but not restricted to the widely discussed list below) become open for all parties subject to the 6 month standstill agreement and we acknowledge the likely stock volatility in the short term for both names. We note that the Francoise Bettencourt Meyers’ statement above emphasises the Bettencourt Meyers family “commitment” and “loyalty” to L’Oréal and “confidence” in management. This suggests no change from a Bettencourt Meyers family perspective, which in theory makes options 4, 5 and 6 more academic.

11:05 am
PM11:06am

Here are the options

PM11:06am

1) Status Quo: All parties do nothing / agree to a further standstill.
2) Sale to L’Oréal A: Nestlé sells its stake in L’Oréal to L’Oréal (with L’Oréal potentially selling its 10% stake in Sanofi and gearing up to ~2x to fund it). Or a partial sale along similar lines.
3) Asset Swap: L’Oréal swaps its 10% stake in Sanofi for ~10% of the Nestlé stake in L’Oréal, reducing the Nestlé holding from 23% to 13.4%.
4) Sale to L’Oréal B: Bettencourt Meyers family sells its stake to L’Oréal (with L’Oréal selling its stake in Sanofi and gearing up to ~4x to fund it). Or a partial sale along similar lines.
5) Nestlé Control: Nestlé buys the Bettencourt Meyers family stake and takes control of L’Oréal (with Nestlé gearing up to 1.5x).
6) Third Party: A third party agrees to buy either the Bettencourt Meyers or the Nestlé stake.

BE11:06am

Yes, those are the options. True.

11:07 am
BE11:07am

Remember we have six months here to chew over the options, most likely.

PM11:07am

There's so much grey on this this morning

PM11:07am

It's as tho the death of the 95 year hasnt come as a shock

11:07 am
PM11:07am

Do you think the sells-side may have pre-written some of this?

BE11:08am

Well, yes. The research putting Nestle together with L'Oreal has been written since 1974.

BE11:08am

The question overhanging it all is, "why?"

11:08 am
BE11:08am

Why would Nestle want L'Oreal?

BE11:09am

They already have a load of JVs, the overlap is minimal .....

BE11:09am

.... cost savings would be head office.

11:09 am
BE11:09am

L'Oreal has, historically, not wanted to be bought.

BE11:10am

Olivetree offered a handy summary of Nestle's acquisition criteria:

BE11:10am

Nestle has a strictly defined “Acquisition Criteria”, some of which L’Oreal meets but others where it clearly does not. These are (1) To create #1 or strong #2 market player (2) Focused approach on value added growth categories (3) Strong brands in leadership positions (4) High certainty of successful integration (5) Organic Growth, Cash Flow & Earnings Enhancing (6) Generate quantifiable value. An acquisition of L’Oreal clearly meets the first two hurdles but the more mathematical tests are questionable.

11:10 am
BE11:10am

Now, Nestle has a CMD arranged for Sept 26th.

BE11:11am

It seems reasonably likely that management will make noises about staying disciplined and not overpaying and stuff.

BE11:11am

At which point the story reverses.

11:11 am
PM11:11am

They are going to be under some pressure at this cap markets day tho

PM11:12am

In what sense does the story reverse tho?

BE11:12am

In the sense that Nestle's plans aren't governed by what its management thought was strategically sensible when Nixon was president.

11:13 am
BE11:13am

Just as plausible that Nestle's L'Oreal stake becomes an overhang.

BE11:13am

Natixis:

BE11:13am

The debate about whether such a link-up makes sense (we still think it would) no longer arises really for financial reasons L’Oréal’s market capitalisation is €100bn. Nestlé owns 23% (129,881,021 shares) and Thétys 33.31%. It would thus have to shell out at least €44bn (not including a premium). And, while Nestlé’s balance sheet is very solid, its deleveraging capacity has diminished significantly. In 2018, out of CHF13bn of operating cash flow, CHF4.9bn is earmarked for capex and CHF7bn for dividends, which only leaves CHF2bn for net debt of CHF16bn at end-2017.

11:13 am
BE11:14am

For the time being, it is Nestlé that needs L’Oréal. In the medium term, the status quo is likely to be maintained unless a very large acquisition is found to offset the dilution. The stake in L’Oréal generates 10% of Nestlé’s EPS. This is important for a group whose current EPS grew by no more than 2% between 2010 (CHF3.32) and 2016 (CHF3.40).

BE11:14am

Anyway, enough of that.

PM11:14am

PM11:14am

11:19 am

BE11:20am

(@Fatdaz: though I also accept the moral issues with this stance.)

PM11:20am

https://ftalphavil...046/taxi-for-uber/

11:19 am
BE11:20am

header made me smile

11:20 am
undefined
PM11:21am

Market boring at the index level -- so lets go to Smiths Group

PM11:21am

Im intrigued by this

11:21 am
PM11:21am

Couldnt immediately see what was wrong with the numbers

PM11:22am

But shrewdies had been looking at Smiths in advance

PM11:22am

Sensing that something was amiss

11:22 am
PM11:22am

But what am I amissing?

PM11:22am

Down 4.4% now

PM11:22am

and it's been substantially lower

11:22 am
Smiths Group PLC (SMIN:LSE): Last: 1,530, down 83 (-5.15%), High: 1,578, Low: 1,515, Volume: 1.41m
PM11:22am

Finals here https://www.invest...1709220700035010R/

BE11:23am

Tad weak, and had a run into the numbers. Though as always with Smiths there are too many moving parts to knock into one sentence.

11:23 am
PM11:23am

Yeah, ok

BE11:23am

H2 revenue of £1,664m is 1% below consensus

BE11:24am

Detection and Medical were worse, Interconnect and Flextek were better.

11:24 am
BE11:24am

And the 2018 outlook, while it's okay, is tilted towards the back end of the year.

BE11:25am

As in, flat margins and more on R&D.

BE11:25am

RBC incoming.

11:25 am
BE11:26am

H2 beat on margins. FY 2017 sales/EBITA/EPS of £3,280m/£589m/97.6p compared with consensus (company website) estimates of £3,296m/£580m/97.0p so a 2% the ‘headline’ trading level for the full year and 3% for the second half. Underlying (organic) revenue growth was -1% year-on-year for the full year, implying - H2 – a slowdown from H1’s flat. Net debt was £967m including an £85m working capital inflow, which we see as a good result.

BE11:26am

Medical – no sign of sales growth yet. Organic revenue growth was -3% y/y for the full year, implying H2 was -4%. All three areas saw declines for the year and into ‘higher-growth regions’ were down 12%. It seems that product launch delays are the primary cause – management had previously guided to some growth in The operating margin of 22.0% (H2 23.0%) was ahead of our 21.6% estimate. Medical growth is expected to improve in the second half of FY’2018 as new pro launches begin to have an effect.

BE11:26am

John Crane – aftermarket declined in H2. Organic revenue for the full year of -4% implied the same run rate in H2 as in H1. Aftermarket sales were +1% y/y at the year after having been +3% at H1. The operating margin in H2 was 25.3% compared to consensus’ 23.6% estimate. The outlook is for growth in aftermarket and O&G, offsetting challenging O&G markets.

11:27 am
BE11:28am

Skipping detection because the RBC PDF's a bit broken.

BE11:28am

Outlook – expecting growth in 2018. The company expects a return to growth in FY’2018, weighted towards the second half (Medical product introducti.... comparative in Detection). We see the results as in-line – slightly disappointing on underlying growth but continued improvements in profitability. Higher central costs may see consensus EBITA reduce a little (~2%), offset by a slightly better tax rate outcome than previously flagged (FY’2018 rate thought to be 29.5%-30.0% from previous 30.0-31.0%). We continue to believe that the Group can return to underlying positive growth in FY’2018, and the management commentary is supportive that, albeit we may have to wait until the second half to see it.

PM11:28am

I can give you CS on detection if you want

11:28 am
BE11:28am

In fact, it's really quite broken indeed. Hope you can make sense of that.

BE11:28am

Yes, CS would be useful.

PM11:29am

Just on detection, otherwise we'll be swamped in grey

11:29 am
PM11:29am

Revenue grew 4% organically, supported by growth in the air transportation market (+9% YoY organically) and in the Asia Pacific region. Focus on aftermarket supported growth in revenue and aftermarket revenue now accounts for 39% of total revenue (2016: 37%).■ By segment, Ports & Borders decreased by 2% on an underlying basis on a strong comparator. Underlying revenue in military decreased by 2% as a number of US military programmes started to wind down, partly offset by stronger growth in EMEA. Urban security revenues were flat on an underlying basis with strong growth in Asia and sales to emergency responders in the US, offset by lower sales elsewhere. Smiths continued to experience pressure on government budgets in all regions, which was most marked in the US due to the effect of the Continuing Budget Resolution■ Headline operating profit grew 21% on an underlying basis and margin improved by 200bps YoY to 15.0%. This growth in profitability was despite continued competitive pricing pressure on large programme contracts and the ongoing challenge from lower-priced competitors in unregulated parts of the market.■ For the four months since completion Morpho delivered headline revenue of £62m and headline operating profit of £8m with good air transportation sales during the second half of the year, including deliveries to the US TSA. The integration of Morpho is progressing.■ Investment in R&D increased during the year, accounting for 7.1% of sales, or 6.0% excluding customer funded R&D (2016: 5.2% and 4.7% respectively).

PM11:30am

What's Morpho?

BE11:30am

He's in the Fantastic 4 I think.

11:30 am
BE11:30am

No idea.

PM11:30am

Think it's a french thing they bought

PM11:30am

Not sure

11:30 am
undefined
BE11:31am

Weird. Ten minutes on Smiths Group hasn't managed to move the ROTR on from moaning about taxis.

PM11:31am

hehehe

11:31 am
PM11:31am

Uber's a talking point if nothing else

BE11:32am

God, is it. It's coming to replace house prices in Dinner Party Live.

BE11:33am

Anyway, on this side of the page we should try and get on.

11:33 am
BE11:33am

You seen this big Goldman thing?

PM11:01am

Welcome to ML

BE11:33am

11:33 am
PM11:33am

er, no

BE11:33am

It's good! It's readable!

BE11:33am

As in, it's written with the idea that it's for humans rather than machines. Which makes it an outlier in the Goldman research canon.

11:33 am
BE11:34am

There's even a Q&A in there, with Lord Brian Griffiths of Fforestfach.

BE11:34am

Goldman's VC, but also head of the No 10 policy unit under Thatcher.

BE11:34am

(And, allegedly, the person who told Thatcher her time was up. The Welsh coup, we called it back in the day.)

11:34 am
BE11:34am

Anyway, it's even a good interview. The gist is that repairing the damage done by QE is a bigger problem than Brexit.

PM11:34am

PM11:35am

That's Lord Brian Griffiths of Fforestfac

11:34 am
BE11:35am

That's him, though he's rather more grey these days.

BE11:35am

Let me get a few quotes.

BE11:35am

I realise there are many possibilities as we negotiate Brexit, but I don't see that as the major challenge at present. What I see as the major challenge is much more a traditional problem, to deal with macroeconomic policy and, in particular, the Bank of England’s conduct of monetary policy.

11:35 am
BE11:35am

We have unemployment at its lowest level for 42 years, which is surely below the natural rate. We've had interest rates of 0.5% or less for seven years. That has channeled investment in speculative areas such as property, property development and consumer spending, rather than into raising productivity in business through investment, and through higher real wages.

BE11:36am

It'd be cheap to pick up on the fact that a Goldman VC is railing against the dangers of speculative investment. Onwards.

BE11:36am

I think that the Bank of England’s forward guidance over the last four or five years has led to confusion undermining the credibility of policy rather than strengthening it.

11:36 am
BE11:36am

The problem now is that compensation in the public sector has fallen behind compensation in the private sector so that public sector trade unions are becoming more militant. And it's not just a reflection of a political outlook but public sector entities like schools, hospitals and so on are simply not able to get the staff they need.

BE11:36am

I can see inflation rising triggered by higher public sector wage growth which, with a loose monetary policy, will give us inflation for the longer term.

BE11:36am

On politics, he doesn't offer much more than a summary of where we are, with a minority goverment formed out of an uncomfortable coalition just trying to hold things together.

11:37 am
BE11:37am

Though his answer to the concluding "are you optimistic?" question is worth quoting.

BE11:37am

If you say what is likely to happen in five years’ time, I don't know. But I would say that if we were able to get the right policy – get on top of controlling public spending, offer lower taxes, invest more in infrastructure, strike new trade deals, then we can raise productivity and growth. And I think that really is the political challenge. The reason I believe it’s possible is that we did it in the 1980s under Mrs. Thatcher’s governments.

BE11:37am

That's the blue-sky scenario. A rerun of Thatcherism. Good luck everyone.

11:37 am
PM11:37am

Lofty ambitions, sure

PM11:38am

But controlling public spending while raising public wage growth...

PM11:38am

And fixing everything from trade to infrastructure

11:38 am
BE11:38am

Anyway, it's a good note, full of non-wonky stats and measured commentary that mostly says "things are getting worse".

PM11:38am

ok

PM11:39am

From the headline i had assumed this was upbeat

11:39 am
BE11:39am

It's "things are getting worse but they might get better, depending on whether that iceberg melts before we hit it."

BE11:39am

So, sort of upbeat.

BE11:40am

Do read, if you get the chance.

11:39 am
undefined
PM11:40am

Worth revisiting Johnson Matthey?

PM11:40am

This battery stuff is another talking point

11:40 am
BE11:40am

Yeah! it's a battery company now!

PM11:40am

All with £200m of investment

BE11:41am

That's it. Chucking £200m at some amazing new stuff they've grown in a lab that doesn't use cobalt and will make electric cars a bit more viable.

11:41 am
BE11:41am

They say.

BE11:41am

eLNO.

BE11:42am

Most disappointingly, no analyst has titled their note "Tickle me, eLNO". Exane's take is pretty good despite that omission.

11:42 am
BE11:43am

With one presentation, JMAT appears to have transformed confidence in its future battery materials offer – and with it, possibly begun to address long-term “existential” doubts. JMAT may now join Umicore in being seen as one of the few quoted electric vehicle plays in Europe. This is supported by strong (and sustainable) recent market share gains in autocats. Despite its outperformance this week, we note JMAT still trades at a 25-35% discount to Umicore on most multiples (though there remain some good reasons why that might not close completely).

BE11:43am

So, what's eLNO?

BE11:43am

As we hoped, JMAT presented a show-stopping update of its cathode offer. eLNO (enhanced Lithium-Nickel-Oxide) was developed in under a year (and is proprietary/patented). However, it already has promising customer feedback and appears to outperform the existing gold-standard (NMC). The development speed appears to underline the strength of JMAT’s core science, and leverages the chemistry overlap between cathode and catalysts. JMAT expects to approve a GBP200m plant in mid-2018 (as customer contracts start crystallising), and significant sales volume from FY22.

11:43 am
PM11:44am

hmm

BE11:44am

There were other positives in the statement, mostly around the gradual slope of decline for autocatalysts, but we don't care about those any more.

PM11:45am

hehehe

11:45 am
BE11:45am

Because JMAT's now a battery company so is worth 20% more than it was on Wednesday. And that's because it's spending £200m on a pilot programme.

PM11:45am

(Cojock
-- Kadhim's looking at it)

BE11:46am

Morgan Stanley ........

11:47 am
BE11:47am

Based on JM's approximated cost of $30/kg for the cathode material, and adjusting for the fact that at today's metal prices ~$20/kg relates to the raw material pass through, then the market opportunity for cathode producers equates to ~$10/kg. Taking our forecasts for cathode material demand by 2025 ~800kt then this would imply a global market opportunity of $8bn. If we assume then that JM could take a market share of 5% and assume the long term return target of 20% implies $80m additional operating profit contribution. This of course does not take into account the lower metal pass through thanks to cobalt thrifting or increased energy density expected from eLNO.

BE11:48am

Did I say cobalt free? What I meant is low-cobalt. At least 50% less cobalt.

BE11:48am

While JM's new material still uses some cobalt, the company
expects the demand to be less than that of NMC (8,1,1) which implies a greater than 50% decline in cobalt content per kWh from today NMC (6,2,2). This is clearly an attractive proposition for OEMs, given materially higher metal cost of cobalt, and the fact that this small geographically concentrated market is susceptible to large price swings.

11:48 am
BE11:48am

Bottom line. We expect that near term, investors will be focussed on the merits of JM's new cathode material in terms of (1) what value should be ascribed, and (2) how large the market opportunity could be should this new technology prove to deliver a step change. However, it is important to acknowledge that there is still further progress to be made to secure customer contracts, and then scale up the necessary capacity. One thing is clear, perception is changing in regards to JM's ability to carve out a market position in the high growth EV supply chain as the powertrain evolves.

BE11:48am

You get the idea.

BE11:51am

11:52 am

PM11:53am

Actually, worth sharing the update on the allAgents site

PM11:53am

From yesterday

11:53 am
PM11:53am

Not only, it appears, does Purplebricks not like what our reviewers say about them on allAgents, but they're also rather miffed about what we wrote about the suspension of the Purplebricks profile on our site. So, due to the further threat of litigation from Purplebricks, we've decided to remove it, despite it being entirely factually correct. We're a small company, and we just don't have the money for a prolonged court battle against a Plc with a market cap of £1 billion. We hope you'll understand.

In our humble opinion the thousands they're paying their lawyers to write to us might have been better spent responding in a positive way to the criticisms raised by our reviewers.

PM11:53am

https://www.allage...o.uk/purplebricks/

PM11:54am

They'll be right at home in the litigant heaven -- on the other side of the pond

11:54 am
BE11:54am

Oh, speaking of litigation, that reminds me:

BE11:54am

http://www.propert...-determination.pdf

BE11:55am

Kenneth Bruce is the other founder of Purplebricks. The one who stepped off the board a couple of weeks before the IPO process.

11:55 am
PM11:55am

Ah, interesting...

BE11:55am

I don't think that link up there is anything incriminating, to be clear. I just note it here for completeness.

Bit left field, but New World Oil and Gas ?

PM11:57am

New World Oil and Gas plc announces that Adam Reynolds has resigned as a director of the Company, effective from 19 September 2017 in order to concentrate on his other business interests.

PM11:57am

PM11:59am

Let's just leave it there

Former Branston & Gothard broker
